lesson.name: Lesson 2.11: Graphing Linear Inequalities in Two Variables, Part 2

page.title: 2.11.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will deepen your understanding of the solutions to linear inequalities by studying them in context. You will write inequalities in two variables to represent constraints, and interpret the points on a boundary line and on either side of it in terms of the situation.

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to:

  • Interpret points in the coordinate plane and decide if they are solutions to the inequality, given a two-variable inequality that represents a situation.
  • Find the solutions to a two-variable inequality by using the graph of a related two-variable equation.
  • Write inequalities to describe the constraints in a situation.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 2.11.1: Sketching a Graph to Represent an Equation
  • 2.11.2: Writing an Inequality to Represent a Constraint
  • 2.11.2: Self Check 
  • 2.11.3: Graphing Solutions and Interpreting Points
  • 2.11.3: Self Check 
  • 2.11.4: Reasoning Points Along Boundary Line (Optional)
  • 2.11.5: Recognizing Points for an Inequality

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 2.11.6: Practice
  • 2.11.7: Summary

page.title: 2.11.1: Sketching a Graph to Represent an Equation
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

A homeowner is making plans to landscape her yard. She plans to hire professionals to install grass sod in some parts of the yard and flower beds in other parts.

Grass sod installation costs $2 per square foot and flower bed installation costs $12 per square foot. Her budget for the project is $3,000.




1. Write an equation that represents the square feet of grass sod, x, and the square feet of flower beds, y, that she could afford if she used her entire budget.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(2x+12y=3,000\) (or equivalent)



2. On the coordinate plane, sketch a graph that represents your equation. Be prepared to explain your reasoning.


Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

page.title: 2.11.2: Writing an Inequality to Represent a Constraint
page.contents:
Activity

The homeowner is worried about the work needed to maintain a grass lawn and flower beds, so she is now looking at some low-maintenance materials.

 She is considering a combination of the materials shown to cover the yard. Her budget is still $3,000.

  •  artificial turf: $15 per square foot
  • gravel: $3 per square foot

Here is a graph representing some constraints in this situation.



1. The graph shows a line going through \((500,100)\).

  1. In this situation, what does the point \((500,100)\) mean?
  2. Write an equation that the line represents.
  3. What do the solutions to the equation mean?


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers to the sample responses:

  1. The cost of installing 500 square feet of gravel and 100 square feet of artificial turf is $3,000. 
  2. \(3x+15y=3,000\)
  3. The solutions are all combinations of square feet of gravel and artificial turf that would cost $3,000 to install.



2. The point \((600,200)\) is located to the right and above the line.

  1. Does that combination of turf and gravel meet the homeowner's constraints? Explain or show your reasoning.
  2. Choose another point in the same region (to the right and above the line). Check if the combination meets the homeowner's constraints.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers to the sample responses:

  1. No. Sample reasoning: If she installs 600 square feet of gravel and 200 square feet of turf, the cost is \(3(600)+15(200)\), which is \(1,800+3,000\) or $4,800.
  2. Sample response: \((900,50)\). This combination would cost more than $3,000 to install.



3. The point \((200,100)\) is located to the left and below the line.

  1. Does that combination of turf and gravel meet the homeowner's constraints? Explain or show your reasoning.
  2. Choose another point in the same region (to the left and below the line). Check if the combination meets the homeowner's constraints.


Enter your answer here:

Compare your answers to the sample responses:

  1. Yes. Sample reasoning: \(3(200)+15(100)=2,100\). This amount is less than $3,000.
  2. Sample response: (600,25). This combination would cost under $3,000 to install.



4. Write an inequality that represents the constraints in this situation. Explain what the solutions mean and show the solution region on the graph.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Compare your answer: 

 

\(3x+15y\leq3,000\). Sample explanation: The solutions represent all possible combinations of square feet of gravel and turf that would cost no more than $3,000 to install.



Video: Writing an Inequality to Represent a Constraint

Watch the following video to learn more about representing constraints using inequalities.

page.title: 2.11.2: Self Check
page.contents: A builder is using a mix of different tiles to remodel a kitchen. The marble tiles cost, x, $15 per square and the ceramic tiles, y, cost $7 per square. The total amount allowed for tiles is at most $900. Which inequality represents this situation?

answer.response: That's correct! Check yourself: The cost of marble tiles, 15x, plus the cost of the ceramic tiles, 7y, is at most $900..
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This inequality does not allow for the project to cost exactly $900? The answer is \(15x\;+\;7y\;\leq\;900.\)
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way:  The total cost of the tiles requires addition, not subtraction. The answer is \(15x\;+\;7y\;\leq\;900.\)
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This inequality has a cost of $22 for both kinds of tiles.The answer is \(15x\;+\;7y\;\leq\;900.\)

page.title: 2.11.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints

Example 

Elena needs to earn at least $450 a week during her summer break to pay for college. She works two jobs. One as a swimming instructor that pays $9 an hour and the other as an intern in a genetics lab for $22.50 per hour. How many hours does Elena need to work at each job to earn at least $450 per week?

Let x be the number of hours she works teaching swimming and let y be the number of hours she works as an intern. 

Write an inequality that would model this situation.

She earns $9 per hour at the job as a swimming instructor and $22.50 in the genetics lab. At each job the number of hours multiplied by the hourly wage will give the amount earned at that job.



Try It: Writing Inequalities to Represent Constraints

A baker sells pies and cakes at the bakery. Each pie sells for $14 and each cake sells for $23. Between all the sales, the baker wants to earn at least $525. How many pies and cakes does the baker need to sell to meet their goal?



Let p be the number of pies sold and let c be the number of cakes sold. Write an inequality that would model this situation.

Enter your answer here:

Here is how to model the situation with an inequality:

\(14p\;+\;23c\;\geq\;525\)

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.11.3: Graphing Solutions and Interpreting Points
page.contents:
1. Activity

A vendor at the Saturday Market makes $9 profit on each necklace she sells and $5 profit on each bracelet.

  1. Find a combination of necklaces and bracelets that she could sell and make:
    1. exactly $100 profit
    2. more than $100 profit

Enter your answer here:

Possible responses:

  1. 10 necklaces and 2 bracelets
  2. 0 necklaces and 21 bracelets


  1. Write an equation whose solution is the combination of necklaces and bracelets she could sell and make exactly $100 profit.

Enter your answer here:

Sample answer: \(9n+5b=100\), where n represents the number of necklaces sold and b represents the number of bracelets.


  1. Write an inequality whose solutions are the combinations of necklaces and bracelets she could sell and make more than $100 profit.

Enter your answer here:

\(9n+5b>100\)


  1. Graph the solutions to your inequality.

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.


  1. Is (3,18.6) a solution to the inequality? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Sample answers:

  1. Yes, it is. The point (3,18.6) is in the shaded region.
  2. No, it is not. The vendor can't sell 18.6 bracelets.


Extending Your Thinking

  1. Write an inequality using two variables x and y where the solution would be represented by shading the entire coordinate plane.
  2. Write an inequality using two variables x and y where the solution would be represented by not shading any of the coordinate plane.

Enter your answers here:

  1. \(x^2+y^2\geq0\)
  2. \(x^2+y^2<0\)

page.title: 2.11.3: Self Check
page.contents:
An artist is designing a sculpture to be displayed hanging in the lobby of a museum. She is using x wooden rods and y metal pipes.

  • Each wooden rod, x, weighs 4 pounds.
  • Each metal pipe, y, weighs 7 pounds. 
  • The total weight of these materials cannot be more than 510 pounds. 

Which of these ordered pairs represents an amount of materials that meets the artist’s constraints?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The weight must be less or equal to 510 pounds. This ordered pair yields a total weight of \(240 + 350 = 590\) pounds. The answer is \((70, 20)\).

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Notice x represents the weight of the wooden rod and y represents the weight of the metal pipe. The total must be less than or equal to 510 pounds. This ordered pair yields a total weight of \(80 + 490 = 570\) pounds = The answer is \((70, 20)\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The weight must be less than or equal to 510 pounds. This ordered pair yields a total weight of \(200 + 420 = 660\) pounds? The answer is \((70, 20)\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: 70 wooden rods and 20 metal pipes meets the artist’s constraint.

page.title: 2.11.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Graph Linear Inequalities in Two Variables

Now that we know what the graph of a linear inequality looks like and how it relates to a boundary equation we can use this knowledge to graph a given linear inequality.

Example 

How to Graph a Linear Equation in Two Variables

Graph the linear inequality \(y\;\geq\;34x\;-\;2.\)

Step 1. Identify and graph the boundary line.

·         If the inequality is \(\leq\) or >\(\geq\) boundary line is solid.

 

·         If the inequality is < or >, the boundary line is dashed.

Replace the inequality sign with an equal sign to find the boundary line

 

\(y=\frac34x-2.\)

 

The inequality sign is \(\geq\), so we draw a solid line.

Step 2. Test a point that is not on the boundary line. Is it a solution of the inequality?

We’ll test (0,0).

 

Is it a solution of the inequality?

At \((0, 0)/), is \(y\geq\frac34x-2.\)?

 

\(0\overset?\geq\frac34(0)-2\)

 

\(0\geq-2\)

 

So, \(90,0)\) is a solution.

Step 3. Shade in one side of the boundary line.

·         If the test point is a solution, shade in the side that includes the point.

 

·         If the test point is not a solution, shade in the opposite side.

The test point  \(0,0)\) is a solution to \(y\geq\frac34x-2.\) So we shade in that side.

 

All points in the shaded region and on the boundary line represent the solutions to \(y\geq\frac34x-2.\)


Try It: Graph Linear Inequalities in Two Variables

Graph the linear inequality \(y\;>\;\frac52x\;-\;4\)

Write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Here is how to graph the linear inequality:

All points in the shaded region represent the solutions to \(y\;>\;\frac52x\;-\;4\)


How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 2.11.4: Recognizing Points Along Boundary Line (Optional)
page.contents:
Optional Activity

A popular band is trying to raise at least $20,000 for charity by holding multiple concerts at a park. It plans to sell tickets at $25 each. For each 2-hour concert, the band would need to pay the park $1,250 in fees for security, cleaning, and traffic services.

The band needs to find the combinations of number of tickets sold, t, and number of concerts held, c, that would allow it to reach its fundraising goal.


1. Write an inequality to represent the constraints in this situation.

Enter your answer here:

\(25t-1,250c\geq20,000\)


2. Graph the solutions to the inequality on the coordinate plane.

Enter your answer here:


3. Name two possible combinations of number of tickets sold and number of concerts held that would allow the band to meet its goal.

Enter your answer here:

Sample response: (1000,2)(1000,2) and (1400,5)


4. Which combination of tickets and concerts would mean more money for charity:

a. 1,300 tickets and 10 concerts, or 1,300 tickets and 5 concerts?
b. 1,600 tickets and 16 concerts, or 1,200 tickets and 9 concerts?
c. 2,000 tickets and 4 concerts, or 2,500 tickets and 10 concerts?

Enter your answer here:

Sample responses:
a. 1,300 tickets and 5 concerts
b. 1,600 tickets and 16 concerts.
c. 2,500 tickets and 10 concerts

page.title: 2.11.5: Recognizing Points for an Inequality
page.contents:
Cool Down Activity

To raise money for after-school programs at an elementary school, a group of parents is holding a weekend of games in a community center. They charge $8 per person for entry into the event. The group would like to earn at least $600, after paying a cost of $40 per hour to rent the space.

1. If \( x \) represents the number of entry tickets sold and \( y \) the hours of space rental, which inequality represents the constraints in the situation?
a. \( 8x-40y<600 \)
b. \( 8x-40y\leq600 \)
c. \( 8x-40y>600 \)
d. \( 8x-40y\geq600 \)

Enter your answer here:

d. 8x−40y≥600


2. The line is the graph of \(8x−40y=600\). Select all points whose \((x,y)\) values represent the group reaching its fundraising goal. Explain or show your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Points B and C. Sample explanation: When the coordinates of B and C are substituted for the \(x\) and \(y\) in the equation, they result in a number that is at least 600.


3. Complete the graph so that it represents solutions to an inequality that represents this situation. (Be clear about whether you want to use a solid or dashed line.)

Enter your answer here:

page.title: 2.11.6: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

For questions 1-4, use the following passage:

Harrison works two part time jobs. One at a gas station that pays $11 an hour and the other is IT troubleshooting for $16.50 an hour. Between the two jobs, Harrison wants to earn at least $330 a week. How many hours does Harrison need to work at each job to earn at least $330?

1. Let x be the number of hours he works at the gas station and let y be the number of (hours he works troubleshooting. Which inequality correctly models this situation?

Correct! \(11x + 16.5y ≥ 330\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(11x + 16.5y ≥ 330\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


2. Which graph correctly represents the inequality from the previous question?

a.

b.

c.

d.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is c. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


3. Which of the following ordered pairs is a solution to the inequality?

 

Correct! (10, 20)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (10, 20). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


4. Which of the following is true about the solution you found in the previous question?

Correct! The solution represents a work schedule that earns him more than $330 per week.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is that the solution represents a work schedule that earns him more than $330 per week.. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 5-8, use the following passage:

The doctor tells Maya she needs to exercise enough to burn 500 calories each day. She likes to run which burns 15 calories per minute or bike which burns 10 calories per minute.

5. If x is the number of minutes that Maya runs and y is the number of minutes she bikes, find the inequality that models the situation.

Correct! \(15x + 10y ≥ 500\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(15x + 10y ≥ 500\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


6. Which graph correctly represents the inequality from the previous question?

a.

b.

c.

d.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is c. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


7. Which of the following ordered pairs is a solution to the inequality?

 

Correct! (15, 30)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (15, 30). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


8. Which of the following is true about the solution you found in the previous question?

 

Correct! The solution represents a workout which allows Maya to burn at least 500 calories.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is that the solution represents a workout which allows Maya to burn at least 500 calories. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


For questions 9-12, use the following passage:

Armando’s workouts consist of kickboxing and swimming. While kickboxing, he burns 10 calories per minute and he burns 7 calories a minute while swimming. He wants to burn at least 600 calories each day.

9. If x is the number of minutes that Armando will kickbox and y is the number of minutes he will swim, find the inequality that will help Armando create a workout for today.

 

Correct! \(10x + 7y ≥ 600\)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(10x + 7y ≥ 600\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


10. Which graph correctly represents the inequality from the previous question?

a.

b.

c.

d.

Correct!

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is b. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


11. Which of the following ordered pairs is a solution to the inequality?

Correct! (20, 70)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is (20, 70). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?


12. Which of the following is true about the solution you found in the previous question?

Correct! The x-coordinate represents the number of minutes that Armando swims.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 2.11.2 and 2.11.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is that the x-coordinate represents the number of minutes that Armando swims. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 2.11.7: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Interpret points in the coordinate plane and decide if they are solutions to the inequality, given a two-variable inequality that represents a situation.
  • Find the solutions to a two-variable inequality by using the graph of a related two-variable equation.
  • Write inequalities to describe the constraints in a situation.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 2.11.1: Sketching a Graph to Represent an Equation
    • In this activity, you reviewed writing and graphing an equation that represents a situation. This prepared you to write linear inequalities that represent constraints in situations and graphing the solution regions.
  • 2.11.2: Writing an Inequality to Represent a Constraint
    • In this activity, you wrote an inequality to represent a constraint in a situation. You graphed a related equation, interpreted the coordinate pairs of points on the graph and on either side of the graph, and tested the pairs of values to see if they make the inequality true. You then used these observations to determine the solution region to the inequality.
  • 2.11.2: Self Check 
  • 2.11.3: Graphing Solutions and Interpreting Points
    • In this activity, you continued to work with inequalities in two variables in context. You wrote an inequality that represents the constraints in a situation, graphed its solutions, and interpreted points in the solution region.
  • 2.11.3: Self Check 
  • 2.11.4: Recognizing Points Along Boundary Line (Optional)
    • In this activity, you had an additional opportunity for writing a linear inequality in two variables to represent constraints and for graphing and interpreting the solutions.

  • 2.11.5: Recognizing Points for an Inequality
    • In this activity, you had more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas and receive guidance for what to look for to identify when an inequality represents the constraints in a situation.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 2.11.6: Practice

Checking In 

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
